sect1.title: Defining the Identity of your Server

sect2.title: Requesting your own Certificate
sect2.para: In order to obtain a certificate you need to create a certificate request. This will contain information about your organization and more sprecifically about the server that is to be authenticated through the certificate. You then need to submit the request to a certificate authority (CA) of your choice. The CA will return your certificate that contains the information that you have provided plus their digital signature that establishes the trust in your certificate.
You can use NEXUSe2e to create a certificate request or use third party tools that you might already use or are most familiar with.

caution.para: When the certificate request gets created the system also generates the so called public and private key pair that is the basis for the cryptographic mechanism on which digital certificates are built. These keys are automatically associated with the request in the NEXUSe2e system. When you delete the certificate request these keys will be lost. Any certificate that gets issued by a CA for such a deleted request will be rendered useless. Creating a new request with the same information will not create the same key pair again and will not match the certificate.

sect2.para: To create a new certificate request navigate to NEXUSe2e > Server Configuration > Certificates > Certificate Request > Create Request. The following screen will appear:
Enter the information for your company and server. The Common Name is the name the server is know under to parnter companies i.e., on the Internet e.g., b2b.mycompany.com.

caution.para: Make sure you remember the password you enter on this screen. It will be used later to protect your certificate. The password will also be applied to any backups of your certificate that you can create through the NEXUSe2e UI.

Once you have entered and saved your certificate request it is a good idea to create a backup of your data by navigating to the screen 'Export Full Key Information (Backup)' which will let you save a backup of your request and key pair to a file.

sect2.para: For submitting the request data to a CA you will need to provide them with your request data in a specific format which is typically pasted to a text area on the CA web page. The required data can be found on the screen 'Show Request' in the field 'PEM Encoded Request'.

figure.title: The Certificate Request Data ready for Submission to a CA

sect2.para: To import the certificate received from the CA navigate to the screen 'Import Certificate'. The screen will allow you to browse to the file on your file system and on confirming the import a screen will appear to verify the information of the loaded certificate.

figure.title: Importing the Certificate received from the CA

sect2.para: When you accept the import the certificate will be combined with the private/public key pair from the original request and a keystore containing this information will be saved in the 'Certificate Staging' area.

figure.title: Imported Certificate in Certificate Staging area

sect2.title: Importing a Keystore/Certificate created with other Tools
sect2.para: To load a new certificate into NEXUSe2e it is recommended that you load it into the certificate staging area first. Navigate to NEXUSe2e -> Communications -> Certificates -> Certificate Staging and select 'Import Certificate'. Select the certificate file to import, provide the password and click 'Update' to import. Note that the file has to contain the certificate and your so called private key. The file has to be in PKCS12 format which is typically indicated by a .p12 or .pfx file extension.

figure.title: Importing the new certificate into the staging area

sect2.para: Once the required certificate has been imported into the staging area you can promote it to production. Please note that this will replace the previously configured active certificate and that the operation cannot be undone. In order to promote a certificate navigate to NEXUSe2e -> Communications -> Certificates -> Certificate Staging and click on the certificate entry. This will display further details of the certificate and additional operations for it. Select the 'Promote this Certificate' button. To verify that the promotion worked see section 'Check the status of your Certificate'.

figure.title: Promoting the new certificate into production

sect2.title: Securing the Web Application Server
sect2.subtitle: Synchronize Tomcat Certificate with NexusE2E
sect2.para: In addition to configuring the NexusE2E application with the new certificate the underlying Tomcat Web application server needs to be configured with it as well. Tomcat requires the certificate to be available as a file in the file system. Identify the file location of the certificate currently configured in Tomcat by reviewing the file <install dir>/conf/server.xml. Find the section that starts with 'Connector port="xxxx"' where xxxx is the SSL enabled port of your Tomcat server. Verify that this file location points to the same file that is defined in the file <install dir>/NexusE2E/WEB-INF/web.xml. The file definition can be found in the section 'PrivateKeyStore'. Additionally the certificate password configured in the server.xml files needs to match the one used when importing the certificate into NexusE2E. In case they differ the server.xml file needs to be updated to reflect the password used in the NexusE2E application.

In order to export the certificate from NexusE2E to Tomcat navigate to NEXUSe2e -> Communications -> Certificates -> Server Certificate in the web based administration UI and select the button 'Export this Certificate Chain'. Verify that path listed under 'Predefined Path' matches the file location in the server.xml file. If it does not select the radio button in front of 'Different Position' and provide the correct file location in the text field. Click the 'Export' button to save the file to the file system.

figure.title: Export the server certificate to Tomcat

sect2.para: After the file has been successfully exported the Tomcat server needs to be restarted.
